com.lehman.ic9.net

Class httpClient

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.lehman.ic9.net.httpClient

  • public class httpClient
extends java.lang.Object
    HTTP client class implements a HTTP client managing HTTP connections.
    Author:
    Austin Lehman

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      httpClient(ic9engine Eng, java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> JsObj, java.lang.String ReqUrl)
      Default constructor takes the reference to the script engine to reference later and the request URL string.

      • httpClient

        public httpClient(ic9engine Eng,
                  java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> JsObj,
                  java.lang.String ReqUrl)
           throws java.net.MalformedURLException
        Default constructor takes the reference to the script engine to reference later and the request URL string.
        Parameters:
        Eng - is an ic9engine instance.
        JsObj - is a Map of String - Object with the JS instance of the httpClient for later reference.
        ReqUrl - is a String with the request URL.
        Throws:
        java.net.MalformedURLException - Exception

      • postString

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> postString(java.lang.String PostTypeStr,
                                                                   java.lang.Object Obj,
                                                                   java.lang.String ContentType)
                                                            throws ic9exception,
                                                                   java.lang.NoSuchMethodException,
                                                                   javax.script.ScriptException
        Performs a HTTP POST call and returns the results of the call as a String. The result object sets the response body as the 'content' property of the result object. URL_ENCODED: When post type is set as url_encoded it is expected that the provided object is a JS object with properties set as key/value pairs to be used as the post parameters. In this case ContentType argument is ignored. MULTIPART: When post type is set as multipart it is expected that the provided object is an object/map where the values are httpPart JS objects. (See net/httpPart.js for details.) For each part provided, only the 'name' and 'data' properties need to be set, and the 'data' property is expected to be a Java byte[]. In this case the ContentType argument is ignored. CUSTOM: When the post type is set at custom it is expected that the provided object is either a plain String or a JS Buffer object. The Obj String or Buffer object is written as the body of the request and the ContentType argument must be set. Use this for example when you want to post JSON data. In this case you'd set the Obj as the JSON encoded string and then set ContentType to 'application/json'.
        Parameters:
        PostTypeStr - A String with the post type. (See postType for options.)
        Obj - Is an Object. (See above for details.)
        ContentType - is a String with the request content type.
        Returns:
        A Javascript object with the response.
        Throws:
        ic9exception - Exception
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - Exception
        javax.script.ScriptException - Exception

      • postBinary

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> postBinary(java.lang.String PostTypeStr,
                                                                   java.lang.Object Obj,
                                                                   java.lang.String ContentType)
                                                            throws ic9exception,
                                                                   java.lang.NoSuchMethodException,
                                                                   javax.script.ScriptException
        Performs a HTTP POST call and returns the results of the call as a Buffer object. The result object sets the response body as the 'content' property of the result object. URL_ENCODED: When post type is set as url_encoded it is expected that the provided object is a JS object with properties set as key/value pairs to be used as the post parameters. In this case ContentType argument is ignored. MULTIPART: When post type is set as multipart it is expected that the provided object is an object/map where the values are httpPart JS objects. (See net/httpPart.js for details.) For each part provided, only the 'name' and 'data' properties need to be set, and the 'data' property is expected to be a Java byte[]. In this case the ContentType argument is ignored. CUSTOM: When the post type is set at custom it is expected that the provided object is either a plain String or a JS Buffer object. The Obj String or Buffer object is written as the body of the request and the ContentType argument must be set. Use this for example when you want to post JSON data. In this case you'd set the Obj as the JSON encoded string and then set ContentType to 'application/json'.
        Parameters:
        PostTypeStr - A String with the post type. (See postType for options.)
        Obj - Is an Object. (See above for details.)
        ContentType - is a String with the request content type.
        Returns:
        A Javascript object with the response.
        Throws:
        ic9exception - Exception
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - Exception
        javax.script.ScriptException - Exception

      • putString

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> putString(java.lang.String PostTypeStr,
                                                                  java.lang.Object Obj,

                                                           throws ic9exception,
                                                                  java.lang.NoSuchMethodException,
                                                                  javax.script.ScriptException
        Performs a HTTP PUT call and returns the results of the call as a String. The result object sets the response body as the 'content' property of the result object. URL_ENCODED: When post type is set as url_encoded it is expected that the provided object is a JS object with properties set as key/value pairs to be used as the post parameters. In this case ContentType argument is ignored. MULTIPART: When post type is set as multipart it is expected that the provided object is an object/map where the values are httpPart JS objects. (See net/httpPart.js for details.) For each part provided, only the 'name' and 'data' properties need to be set, and the 'data' property is expected to be a Java byte[]. In this case the ContentType argument is ignored. CUSTOM: When the post type is set at custom it is expected that the provided object is either a plain String or a JS Buffer object. The Obj String or Buffer object is written as the body of the request and the ContentType argument must be set. Use this for example when you want to post JSON data. In this case you'd set the Obj as the JSON encoded string and then set ContentType to 'application/json'.
        Parameters:
        PostTypeStr - A String with the post type. (See postType for options.)
        Obj - Is an Object. (See above for details.)
        ContentType - is a String with the request content type.
        Returns:
        A Javascript object with the response.
        Throws:
        ic9exception - Exception
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - Exception
        javax.script.ScriptException - Exception

      • setTcpNoDelay

        public void setTcpNoDelay(boolean UseTcpNoDelay)
        Sets the flag for TCP no delay. (Nagle's Algorithm) In order for this flag to be effective this must be called prior to making the actual HTTP request.
        Parameters:
        UseTcpNoDelay - is a boolean with true for TCP no delay and false for not.
